OK, I think we can get started. It looks like we'll
get it all done.

In any case, I actually
have slides today. This is a bit of an experiment.

The idea is to basically give
an orientation of a fairly small

topic, but one which I think
is interesting and amusing, and then open it up for
discussion with everybody

who's here to participate. Those of you who are
students at Stanford, please

don't put up your video. Anyone else can put
the video up or not as they wish, because of
the requirement that you

be able to attend
anonymously, if you're a student at university.

In any case, the topic today
is intellectual property and artificial intelligence.

And it's one which is interested
and amused me for the last,

well, I think
probably six months. About six months ago,
I decided that we had

had all sorts of things change. So let's do this. I'm going to
automatically include

all the standard disclaimers
about this, this, and thats, and thank the people who
participated in informing

me a little bit about this. And want to tell everybody
that no artificial intelligence

program participated in the
preparation of this talk. And then thought
about that a bit.

And concluded that, to
the best of my knowledge no artificial intelligence
program participated

in the preparation. But somewhere, somehow
out there in the space,

that might not be longer true. And so the conclusion I
reached six months ago

was that the singularity
is almost here. Now if you don't know
about the singularity,

it's probably not really
transparent what's going on.

But the singularity is
when the massive computing power reaches a
critical point, and it

begins to operate on its own. And in a sense, the
ChatGPT and a number

of the other AI
programs begin to look like that might be the case.

They're good enough, so that
in some ways, in some places, it's very, very difficult
to tell whether or not

they're real. So all of a sudden,
our machine learning

and artificial
intelligence are real, and they are just another
piece of the tool kit

that we get to use,
except that they're not. They're much more
powerful in some ways.

So the question really that
we're trying to address today, is what happens next?

And as a predictor of
the future or rather

a forecaster of the future,
I have not really a real clue

as to what's going to happen. I think this is a very
significant point, a point where

things are changing rapidly. And we're going to see
very major changes.

Now you may have different
opinions of that. And if you do, it
would be really nice to have those
expressed today when
this turns into an open forum.

Intellectual property is a
relatively recent acquisition in the space of things
people, humans, do.

But we do have a
fairly long-standing

constitutional mandate for
intellectual property in the US.

We have two kinds of protections
for intellectual property,

and they are to promote
the progress of science

and the useful
arts by securing-- and the mechanism which
the constitution proposes

as the right one
for doing that is securing for limited times
to authors and inventors

the exclusive rights to
their respective writings and discoveries, that
is to say a monopoly.

We've evolved a number
of different kinds

of protectable intellectual
property, patents and copyrights being the primary one.

Trade secrets are
somewhat different because unlike the previous
two, the patents and copyright,

trade secrets have to do with
how the information is acquired in some sense.

We'll talk a little
bit about that. But that's what it is.

Patents are what you can
do with almost anything.

There's a substantial
set of law and examples

which show that exactly
how patents go together. The important thing is that
patents are now first to file,

which says that ongoing
research and development needs to be patented and patented
again on a regular basis.

If you're disclosing what
you're doing to anybody, it's only after you or you
have it under protection,

for example, with a provisional
patent that you can really

disclose much of the contents
of your research or development.

There are a variety
of different patents. The only one that is
significant in some sense

because it's how things get
done is our utility patents.

Now patents basically take
a collection of information and eventually provide a
preferred embodiment for it,

at least this is a
traditional format, and then also a number
of different claims.

And these claims have
particularly particular constraints on them and rights.

And that needs to be
unique in the world

of all previous thought,
which can be difficult or can be straightforward,
depending upon the field

you're in. There are things that
can't be patented-- discoveries, scientific
theories, mathematical methods,

aesthetic creation,
rules for performing a mental act, a
presentation of information,

and a procedure for surgical
and therapeutic treatment.

You can't patent software
and business methods. That is non-technical ones.

Technical ones are patentable
to a certain extent. You can't patent
perpetual motion machines,

inventions contrary
to public morality, and now we have the recently
acquired Alice constraints

that say an abstract idea does
not become eligible for a patent simply because it's
being implemented

on a generic computer. Copyrights are a
less strong version
of intellectual property.

It does not protect
ideas, concepts, systems, or methods of doing something.

It protects something else. It's what's there, minus
all of those things.

So that it is the essence, or an
idea, or expression of the idea

that is copyright,
not the idea itself.

So original works of authorship
are those done by people.

There are all sorts of rules
about how collective groups can

work together to provide a
collective work of authorship

by transferring rights. In any case, copyrights are
a relatively weaker form

of protection, but one
which is widely used. And of course, when you write
anything, a work of authorship

is automatically copyright.  Most copyright law
stumbles on the separation

of ideas and expression. And because what it
protects is expression.

There's a lot of argument about
what constitutes expression and what constitutes ideas.

And it appears, at least
in the experience I've had, that is going to
continue to be that way.

And what we have to do in
order to determine what what's expression and what
our ideas is go off to court

and to litigate it. There is a concept of fair use. And while the copyright
gives the author or the owner

of the copyright the right
to control access to things,

there's a back door that
allows some access under rules for something called fair use.

Trade secrets are quite
a different thing. These are secret, and
have to be maintained so.

It has to confer a competitive
advantage which usually means that there needs to have been
an analysis on a financial basis

of why it's better to do
it one way or another. The information has to be
subject to reasonable efforts

to keep a secret. Trade secrets are
probably not something

that at least at
this point, are going

to be part of the issues with
the artificial intelligence.

The real fundamental
question for today is can AI programs create.

Is intelligence and
creativity unique to humans? Can artificial
intelligences just

create something
independent of human effort? And that is really important.

The question is should
an algorithm or an AI

be granted legal personhood? Should it be able to
apply for and acquire

patents or copyrights on
work that it generates?

Right now, we'll see in a
minute that the agencies that

create and provide patents and
copyright do not allow that. But it's an open question as to
whether we should allow that.

And that's I think
going to be something that is going to be
fought over aggressively

in the next few years. One of the things I would like
people to think about and talk

about is what the
implications are of allowing AI programs to
have the agency of doing

their own patents and so forth. And is that going
to be a good thing or a bad thing for our society?

You remember back to the
constitutional mandate. The real purpose of
copyrights and patents

is not to give
somebody a monopoly

on a piece of
intellectual property, but rather to allow that
person or those persons

to contribute something to
the overall intellectual bank

of the society as a whole. And the trade that's made
is you get protection

as a monopolist for a
short period of time. And then you have to provide
an adequate description

of the invention or
the work itself for use

after the copyright
or patent expires. And if you do
allow an AI's works

to be created, who would own the
resulting works and inventions?

Incidentally, copyright
terms are often specified in terms of
the author's age or years

in their birth or
something of that ilk. And if AIs don't have
finite lifetimes,

that's an interesting
question itself, as to what the term of
a copyright for a work
of authorship by an AI.

There are lots of things
that we can talk about-- discussing should
the AI be regulated,

should the electrical property
have an ownership, who owns it,

will we soon find
AI in everything,

doing everything
including nefarious deeds. I'm told by a couple of
people in the security area

that it's already doing that,
that the GPT stuff has already

been incorporated in
some malicious software.

So the thing is, I'm
really interested in what the impact is. And since you're the
users for this technology,

you probably have a better idea
of what it is to do than I.

It's also, the thing
that what it always comes down to when people first
encounter thinking about this,

the question is,
are humans important to the creative process?

If you can't detect whether the
output of the creative process was created by a
machine or a human,

does it make any difference? I think that's an
important point when you're

trying to argue that maybe
the AI should be allowed to do their thing, without the
interference or help of a human

being. Right now, the situation
is exactly what

you might expect for things. The patent office does not
accept inventions by non-humans.

The reasoning for
that is several fold,

one of them being
that since non-humans can't sign the application, the
patent office can't accept it.

And then the copyright office
does not support AI authors.

And just recently they
said that was the case.

And several other
organizations who

do copyright outside of the US
have also been rejecting things.

A couple of countries
have allowed for copyrighting of materials
written by AIs under the AI's

identification. But that is not the
common case at this point.

And I think that's
the end of the slides. So what I'd like to do now
is to move to an open forum.

Raise your hand or whatever, or
just step in if there's a break. And ask questions.

Make comments. Tell me a little bit
about what you think the situation ought to be.

I have thought about
this several times, and. I think the implications of the
technology being used and being

somewhat autonomous are
interesting, and perhaps
somewhat disturbing.

If you adopt that
position and note that the AI software is similar
to many other different kinds

of software, and it looks
to me like the AI model

if it becomes
propagating, then it becomes fairly simple to have
automatic thises and thats,

which are not necessarily
based on our current AI models but on much simpler or
much more complicated

programs which also
have the same agency. And it is going to change
the relationship between what

is possible in the
intellectual property arena

and who makes money on things. In any case, I'm going to
drop the slides down now.

And open the thing. Please remember to turn
on your microphone,

if you're interested
in saying something. OK. Here we go.

So there is a question. Who would profit if AI
create some invention--

the creator of the AI or
a guy who actually asked

that AI to do some invention? Or it's maybe a poem, for
example, a technology invention,
or whatever.  Well, I can't answer that.

What do you think
would make sense? I don't know.

It's just new for me,
at least for today. I see. OK, well think about
it as we go on.

And you can come back in if
you come up with a good answer. I think that's going to be one
of the more difficult ones,

particularly since if you
give agency to the AIs and they can do work,
then it's possible

that the slavery or anti-slavery
things come and get brought in.

Because you're
doing servile work without pay for somebody else.

And I'm not certain
that that applies. But it certainly is an
interesting thought, I thought.

All right, and we need to
solve that as fast as possible,

because otherwise it
would be solved in courts. Yes, I think so.

And I think, by the
way, that this is going to be dominant in the next--

I think we'll have
in every AI thises and thats everywhere in the
next 6 to 10 months to a year.

And already, you
see it showing up in various places which
is a little surprising.

If you'll remember when
Benji [? Mensah ?] spoke,

he was talking about how the
patching of images together

into a seamless whole is now
being done with the use of AI. And you can't
disassemble it in order

to tell whether or
not it's faked or not. I was about this
question as well.

And something that came up
was that there are currently some licensing work, because at
present artificial intelligence

is a technology. So it is still not at the level
of consciousness and imitation

of consciousness. It does not mean
that machine has it. For example, the
Turing test, it states

that if machine can
imitate human, therefore it is capable of human thinking.

But it is important to remember
that there is a difference. So syntax is also the
same as semantics,

as [INAUDIBLE]
points out as well. And I agree with this opinion.

But at the present, since we
view it more as a technology, or at least I do, there are more
of a licensing war going on.

As well as currently you have
to pay for certain types of AI,

and then you can own the work. Otherwise, the work belongs
to the creator or the company.

So there are also some
decentralized networks that include the AI. So that's a little
more complicated.

But I think it would really
depend on the type of AI, what it does, and
how we use this work.

Because there are open licenses
for public use and private.

So I think it would
maybe depend what is it, and what the creator decides.

Well, I think that's
a reasonable position.

But you're basically trying
to set it up in such a way

that the current
ownership situation is

as undisturbed as
possible in a sense, that you want to
maintain licensing

and ownership by companies,
and that sort of thing. And that may not be the
right thing to do, I think.

I'm just curious about
exactly what other options there might be.

OK, so I understand
your concern. But currently, also the
companies create AI.

So it's more a private thing. So it definitely would be
good to have some government

intervention I think,
at least partially. Because also there
may be difference.

Because I'm in Europe. So we have a little different
legislation as well,

as European Commission currently
working on the AI policies. So I'm not sure 100% what
is the situation in the US.

But I think that
it would be good, the process of collaboration. Because it is a very
powerful technology.

It also involves a lot of data. So how is also data collected,
and what it gives you

as a result, I think it should
be at least thought together. We should maybe
set a common goal.

But at the present,
since the technology is made by private
sector, I think now there

is a short-term licensing. But if we look in the
future, of course,

maybe as technology
progresses, it may change and we have to be
aware of these changes

and provide new also changes
in legislation or our ideas,

how do we perceive the
technology, particular AI as well.
Yes, OK. Great. Anybody else there?
Yeah. Go ahead. Yes. Yeah, sorry.

The question was, so I'll
reference a number of cases, specifically the case in
which I think it was a macaque

took a picture of
itself, a selfie. And then the owners
of the camera

who had let the monkey
get a handle of it and then take a picture of it.

There you go, that's it. Yeah. Tried to exert copyright
over the images

that the primate took of itself. And then PETA sued
the people who

tried to, for violation of
this primate's copyrights.

And it was based on
actually court findings that if it's not-- I mean, yes, the copyright
office rejected the proposition.

But at the same time
the courts rejected the proposition of
non-human of any sort can exert any kind of copyright.

So that's in the United States,
at least, the jurisprudence is pretty unequivocal
about that.

There has been no successful
challenges to that to that formulation. But the only other way in
which the idea of ownership

has been addressed,
Mary Rasenberger, who is the lead counsel for the
Authors Guild of United States,

in comments to the
copyright office, suggested that perhaps two
solutions could be found. That whatever analogous
to the solutions

found in the monkey
case, which were that if the photographer
set the f-stop,

or if the photographer someone
just intervened in any way,

then by extension it is the
photographer's copyright. So that's part of
the rationale is

why the courts found in favor
of the owners of the camera who had left that in. So I think that
answers the question

as to whether copyright,
in the United States, jurisprudence is pretty
unequivocal about that. Mary suggested that any work,
novel work which over which

there is no overfitting or
plagiarizing or anything like that, as long as a human
being had some hand in it,

even if it was transfer
learning, fine tuning, even if the model showed
up pre-trained

and whatever-- that constitutes
copyrights for a human. And that's the entity
that gets the copyrights.

So Paul Reinitz at Getty,
who is the head of advocacy, he's also a
colleague of mine who

I've sat on panels with,
his determination is--

and we debate-- because
his determination is that now the question
is, how much input

is the metric by which
courts should award. If not, then either the
thing was a violation,

the creation is a violation, or
it goes into the public domain. So now a lot of
policymakers are trying

to find where is the
magic spot, where

it was just right human
intervention for it to constitute human creation. And that's a relative.

People who are
copyright owners are going to want more input
from a human before. Others are going to want a lot
less, like I put a dot somewhere

and that's enough. So I think that's the,
from my understanding and I would encourage
and I'm going

to put in the link Mary
Rasenberger's comments to the copywriter
illuminating in this regard.

And she would like to
have licensing on any AI. So like the HRA, the
Human Recording Act,

the HRA where they passed
on all manufacturers of digital audio
tape recorders had

to pay a licensing fee before
the object got in the market. So the copyright owners
are advocating for that.

Anybody who makes
an AI tech, needs to pay a license to anybody.

How do you deal with the
fact that everything that's written, and every work of
authorship by a human being

is automatically copyright? Correct. And it's like you've invented
technology that could

potentially in the process
of its operation violate copyrights, therefore, if you
invented such a technology,

you have to pay a license to the
original to whatever content you wish to use-- the
musician's, the author's.

Jack Valenti must be
rising from the dead. He's so happy.

At least he was the former
lead counsel for the music--

I mean excuse me
the movie industry. Right? So he's the guy who's famously
said something so egregious in front of Congress, it's
not even worth commenting.

If you want to know,
you can look it up. So that's my comment on that. I think it's just
not going to happen.

The jurisprudence
is pretty solid.

So do you think that the
[? efficacy ?] of the AIs

will get impacted at all
by the rush to having rules

about how the intellectual
property is managed? I think what's going
to happen, it's

going to be a chilling effect. I think unless the tech
industry doesn't get-- because I'll tell you,
Getty is in Europe.

Paul from Getty is
in Europe advocating for this kind of governance.

And they're doing it
in the United States. And I don't see tech companies
really doing anything.

Well, they're doing something. But they're not in
there, in the room, really fighting, in my opinion. So would you advocate
for tech companies

advocating for much looser or
much tighter control on the AI. I think there's going to
have to be a middle ground.

I think Mary
Rasenberger's comments on, let's say the amanuensis thesis
that if we start treating it

like amanuensis, is
anything that it makes is a work for hire. And so whether it's a patent,
so anything an AI makes

becomes a work for hire. And it's the amanuensis. It just helped you. And in that way,
I think it becomes

less of a chilling effect. People are more willing
to say, well, OK. I had AI help, as opposed to
well the AI did most of it,

and then nobody gets to benefit
from the monopoly which was supposed to be an incentive.

I think that covers it. Usually, recently
a number of papers have been submitted to journals
where the AI program was

left as a co-author. And the journals rejected
them, because they

say only human authors. Right. I think it's going
to be a normative, like different fields,
publications, will have

different norms that evolve. But as a matter of
law, the boundaries

are pretty well-defined. And you believe that the
boundaries of law will prevail?

I would think the
argument would have to be a common goods argument. I think something, I've spoken
to other intellectual property

attorneys who suggest that
maybe a Nash equilibrium. Nash equilibrium or those kinds
of economic studies of markets

suggest that actually a
looser copyright, a looser intellectual property
regime, is better for the market as a whole.

And I think that argument
can be made for AI since it's the potential to mass produce,
high quality functional tools.

And the market will benefit. So it inoculates against
the Chicago school jurists,

and then also it
gives some support to the incentivize and progress
of the useful arts camp.

Yeah, OK. Great. Thank you. You're welcome. So the thinking about the
constitutional mandate

is that, there's a bargain
here that we will give you a monopoly if you submit to the
public domain eventually, right?

So we'll give you
a limited time. So that's essentially
incentivizing authors and patent inventors to be able to
put their things out.

So that incentive is
missing from machines. Machines don't need incentives
to be able to create.

And in fact, machines can
spit out millions and billions of things, whereas humans can't
do even a fraction of that.

So my thought is
that constitutionally we don't have a way. We don't need to
incentivize machines

to blanket the world
with copyrightable things and patentable things.

That incentive isn't needed. So as my personal example,
I've created a machine

to spit out and copyright
417 billion melodies. Once they're written to
a fixed tangible medium,

those are now copyrighted right
under the Berne Convention. So are all 417 billion of
my melodies copyrightable?

I set the parameters. And that's the previous speaker
just talked about the f-stop. Right? So I created the f-stop.

I said, here are the parameters. I want do-re-mi-fa-so-la-ti-do. And then I said,
repeat this many notes.

And then it spit out
417 billion melodies. Have I now closed off every
possible melody that's

ever been and ever can be? Can I sue now people for
every possible melody?

I think the answer to
that clearly is no. Because the my
machine didn't need the incentive, the
constitutional incentive,

to be able to get
a monopoly of life of the author plus 70
years, or for a corporate

it's 120 years, if I'm
remembering correctly, 95 or 120 years. 99.

So yeah, so none
of those incentives is necessary for the machine. So I would argue that the only
real good answer on the output

is no copyright. Because machines
don't need incentives. On the input, on what the
machines, like the LLMs,

the large language
models like GPT, and BART, et cetera,
what they input,

if you look at the way
the technology is done, they're ingesting
the ideas and not the expressions of those ideas.

So they're pulling
in the ideas of what

is a good thing, what
is a bad thing, what is a car, what is a truck. And it puts all those
things in vector space

in a mathematical
model, and it jettisons the expressions of those ideas. It merely keeps those
ideas themselves

and then outputs new
expressions of those ideas. So to the previous person's
discussion about maybe

we need to put a tax
on all AI systems, the AI system ingests
Grapes of Wrath,

but it doesn't keep Grapes
of Wrath in the system. Instead, it just takes the
ideas from Grapes of Wrath,

and then jettisons
that expression, and then maps those ideas with
all the thousands or millions

of other books. And then the expression
doesn't matter. The ideas are the only
things that matter.

So I would say that
there's really no reason to have a Home Recording Act.

Because if you look at
the Google scholar case, that's the Authors Guild versus
Google in the Second Circuit,

they said that it's fair use. Because it's a transformative
use to be able to say I

Google am indexing
all of these books. And I Google, can reproduce
three or four pages

of verbatim text
from those books. And that is fair use
as transformative. Compare that with a
large language models,

that again, aren't even
taking those expressions of those books, not
even taking three

pages of those expressions,
but rather it's just taking the ideas of
those books and then reconstituting ideas,
not expressions,

but reconstituting ideas there. So if it's fair use
under Google Books, then wouldn't it also be fair
use under large language models?

Yeah the Google Books has
been argued to be invasive

and non-conforming
to copyright models.

But yeah, I agree with you. I think that's right. It's interesting that you see
this as a separation of idea

from expression in terms
of building the knowledge

base on which all of
these things are based. And it's very interesting.

I think that because if
you look at the models, the large language models,
there is not an expression

to be found in those models. It is merely ideas. In vector space, it takes
the idea of Bob Dylanism.

It takes the idea
of any human author and it doesn't have any of Bob
Dylan's lyrics in the system.

It merely has the idea of what
Bob Dylan, his use of language, right?

So anyway, there is not
an expression to be found.

OK. That's great. So-- Maybe I should also

So that artificial intelligence,

So when I say I like ice cream. So we as people have

What is it ice cream. So think what it also implies
here is that the machine does

not have this deeper
understanding, but it is shuffling the
information, the data.

And I think also maybe
regarding the authorship point, I will start from the end.

Because I made a
couple of notes. So maybe it's not

has participated in

And currently, only

in European Commission
of electronical persons, or electronic persons.

But it was kept just as an idea. So it didn't come into

so maybe not yet, and maybe

So there is a deeper
ontological question. So what is machine
and how do we see it?

Do we see it as
conscious or unconscious.

Because we have animals as well. We have children whose

is under parent guidance or

It legally belongs to

And whether we
should position it on the scale of living

have to understand
the living beings, because non-living
come into play as well.

So it's important to
think it through, I guess. And regarding the free market
that [INAUDIBLE] mentioned,

I think he mentioned
exactly the looser control and I guess the social control
is related to free market.

But there is a possible

that free market can lead to
autocratic behavior in a sense

that big companies own it. Currently we have a free
market economy mostly

in almost everywhere. And the thing is that now the

for example media, like
Facebook who is Meta. So they own many things, as well

So of course, I find that
governmental intervention is necessary. But not like that they
